notes: Note: The Kurdish word is likely written as ئەڵێ in the Sorani script.
you, plural, cf. sh>h a regular sound change in Kurdish
give, Iranic and other IE languages have a similar lexeme
earth, soil, cf Kurdish rt > rd
power, strength, cf. Kurdish u- > w-
lord, compare also with the Semitic ''Amir''
to place down, cf. Kurdish u-> w-
throat, compare also with the Irano-Kurdish garû, and Persian galu, there is also another word in  qurquroska
no; there is also a similar equivalent in Iranic
to carry, there is also a similar equivalent in Iranic
resembles even Iranic, cf. New Persian ''mandan''
to take off, cf. Kurdish a>i
old, cf. m>v but also Iranic ''kohan'' which has led to Kurdish ''kon''
under, foot, cf. even Iranic pey
land, country, field, cf. kurdawari, کوردەواری / warê me وارێ مە
Armenian agarak has been suggested as an Armenian loan from 'awari'. Kurdish has even 'garak' with the same meaning
land, country, field, cf. kurdawari, کوردەواری / warê me وارێ مە
Armenian agarak has been suggested as an Armenian loan from 'awari'. Kurdish has even 'garak' with the same meaning
give, dialectal as in Slêmanî, for example: ''bi-ar-ê'': بیەرێ ''give him''
year, but Iranian ''sard'', New Persian has also ''sal''
year, but Iranian ''sard'', New Persian has also ''sal''
granary, cf Kurdish ha-<-a, notice 'zimharr' زمهاڕ, meaning 'winter granary'
six, but it is the same even in Iranic
name of a native religion in Kurdistan
name of a native religion in Kurdistan
name of a native religion in Kurdistan
low, a low level, position or degree
mistress of the house, beautiful woman
note ''Selardi'', a lunar goddess of Urartu
grapes hanged in order to be sun dried in a vineyard
water infiltration, water dropping, water penetration
plus some other cognates of the word
do, cause to do, used as a preffix for verbs
turn around, also a kids game
not be confused with Arabic 'turbat': soil
to be powerful, to be strong
but cf. also Iranian 'robudan', take away, grab
name of a beloved woman in Kurdish folklore

notes: the big ones, the adult ones
to hold in hands, to press in hands
to send, as in 'hal pasardin': 'to send into exile'
